lead_paragraph: European Union officials in Brussels want uniform rules, but many countries prefer to use tax policies to reward or punish big multinationals.

byline.contributor: James Kanter reported from Brussels, and Mark Scott from Rome. Stephen Castle contributed reporting from London, Elisabetta Povoledo from Rome, and Aurelien Breeden from Paris.
byline.original: By JAMES KANTER and MARK SCOTT

headline.print_headline: Europe Divided Over Taxing Google and Other U.S. Giants
headline.main: Taxing Google and Other U.S. Giants Is Dividing Europe

snippet: European Union officials in Brussels want uniform rules, but many countries prefer to use tax policies to reward or punish big multinationals.
abstract: Europe is split over allowing corporate tax breaks for big United States multinational companies like Google; some nations like France and Germany want to claw back breaks, while others prefer firms keep them to encourage investment and prosperity.
